text: English grammar lesson 21 topic double
comparatives as in the more the merrier
my husband often complains that we live
in a cold climate but I don't mind
because here in New England we have
sunshine almost every day and the
brighter the Sun the happier I feel the
opposite is also true the less Sun the
worse I feel is it the same for you does
the amount of sunshine make you feel a
certain way in this lesson I'd like to
help you learn how to express cause and
effect that's the relationship where one
thing makes a change in another one
thing produces a result in another like
the sunshine making me feel happy to
express cause and effect we're going to
use comparative forms words like
brighter happier so if you're ready
let's begin because the sooner we start
the sooner we finish
I'd like to make sure you understand
cause and effect in the sentence the
brighter the Sun the happier I feel
where's the cause it's here in the first
half that means the effect or the result
is here in the second half what I'm
saying is that when there's bright Sun
I'm happy and if the Sun is even
brighter I'm even happier you just heard
me reword the sentence that's because in
English we can express cause and effect
with more than one structure the
brighter the Sun the happier I feel can
also be written like this when the Sun
is brighter I feel happier or if the Sun
is brighter I feel happier or brighter
Sun makes me feel happier
let's look more closely at the grammar
in this one sentence we have a comma
that separates two ideas the cause and
the effect in each half of the sentence
we have a subject it's what we're
talking about what's the subject in the
first half the son what's the subject in
the second half I now let's talk about
verbs in the second half we have I feel
subject verb if you look back to the
first half where's the verb it's not
written but can you guess what it is
do you understand it's the verb is this
structure allows us to leave out the
verb if it's a form of the verb be it's
understood the brighter the Sun the
happier I feel it may help to see the
structure presented like this the two
halves are separated by a comma it's a
sentence so we must end with the period
both halves begin with the plus a
comparative form of a word the
comparative is followed by a subject and
verb but remember if the subject and
verb can be understood without us
actually writing or saying them we can
leave them out the verbs left out are
forms of the verb B as in the brighter
the Sun the happier I feel when the
subject is left out it's a word like it
or there a word that simply helps us
state the existence or state of
something as in the brighter the better
the brighter it is the better it is
I keep using the term compared to forms
do you understand what I mean in the
sentence the brighter the Sun the
happier I feel the to comparative words
are brighter and happier they describe
things so they're adjectives brighter
describes son happier describes me are
those the only kinds of words that have
comparative forms no in the second
sentence the less sunshine the worse I
feel the comparative forms are less and
worse worse can be used like an
adjective or adverb less is a word that
answers the question how much so
Comparative forms are used for
adjectives adverbs and words that answer
the question how much or how many I
think it would be a good idea right now
to have a quick review of comparative
forms do you agree let's go on
comparative adjectives are often formed
by adding the ending er as in brighter
but there are a couple spelling rules we
need to remember if the adjective ends
in Y we change the Y to an i before
adding ER as in happier if the adjective
ends in consonant vowel consonant then
we double the last consonant as in
hotter some adjectives have an irregular
form bad becomes worse and with longer
words we place more in front of the
adjectives as in more difficult
the word Moore is also used to form many
comparative adverbs as in more quickly
some adverbs share the same forms as
adjectives fast faster could be either
adjectives or adverbs and there are
adverbs that have irregular forms for
example well becomes better
now let's talk about the words more and
less more is the comparative form of
many and much less is the comparative
form of little these words that answer
how much or how many can be placed
before a noun as in the more knowledge
the better or they can stand alone as in
the more the better
let's summarize what we've learned so
far by looking at a very common saying
the more the merrier
have you heard it before do you
understand I'm going to have my friend
Julie explain what it means
Julie do you know the expression the
more the merrier yes I do
can you tell me what do you think it
means more than merrier I would have to
say the more the merrier
would be like if I were saying inviting
you to a party you said oh I'll come and

yeah the more work yeah it's more food
the more noise the more noise yes the
more food yes but yeah it's not worth it
as Julie said the more the merrier means
the more there are the merrier it is in
this sentence the subjects and verbs
were left out in both halves of the
sentence because they're understood we
have to compared two forms the more is
our cause the merrier is our effect what
we're saying is when there are more
people it is merrier it's more fun or if
there are more people it is merrier it
is more fun
exercise one explained the meaning of
the double comparatives by rewording the

bigger the party the more food you must
